title.narrative: IR 1.5 REPONSE AUX URGENCES SANTE&NUTRIT

description.narrative: IR1.5 : By 2018 all crises (epidemics, disasters, displacement, nutrition) receive appropriate and timely health and nutrition response in accordance with CCCs and a minimum complementary health package is offered in areas with displaced population, which contributes to Child Health, Health And Emergencies, Maternal And Newborn Health, Nutrition And Emergencies, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: CHILD SURVIVALPCR1: By end 2018, the proportion of children, newborns, families who benefit from high health impact quality interventions, including HIV Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission (PMTCT), nutrition, and water - sanitation - hygiene (WASH ) increases significantly and fairly, particularly in health sub-divisions and communities.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: IR1.5 : By 2018 all crises (epidemics, disasters, displacement, nutrition) receive appropriate and timely health and nutritionresponse in accordance with CCCs and a minimum complementary health package is offered in areas with displaced population

description.narrative: The number of children 6 to 59 months vaccinated against measles was 1,342,615 (130%). UNICEF procured 8 million measles vaccines and 1,317 measles kits for the medical management of 131,700 children. UNICEF also distributed cholera kits in four affected provinces in addition to Ebola interventions (risk communication and community engagement, infection prevention and control). A scaled-up nutrition response was ensured in 145 health zones which cover 43% of nutrition cluster's priority zones. A total of 436,013 children (49% of UNICEF target and 30% of cluster target) were admitted for treatment of Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) during the reporting period. | Status:Met | As-of Date:07/02/2020
